conclusion: Draw the free-body diagrams for spheres A and B.
Sphere A has weight mg downward, normal force N₁ to the right, static friction f vertically, and normal force N from B.
Sphere B has weight 2mg downward, normal force N₂ to the left, and normal force N from A.
The contact surfaces AB and the right wall are smooth, so there is no friction there; friction exists only between sphere A and the left wall.
Set the geometric angle φ = 30° with the horizontal for the line joining the centers.
Resolve the contact force N into components for spheres A and B.
Write the equilibrium equations for sphere B: N₂ = N cos φ and N sin φ = 2mg.
Write the equilibrium equations for sphere A: N₁ = N cos φ and f = mg + N sin φ.
Insert N sin φ = 2mg into f = mg + N sin φ to get f = 3mg.
Relate friction to the normal force on the wall: f = μN₁.
Using N₁ = N cos φ and replace N by N sin φ = 2mg to get N₁ = 2mg cot φ.
Solve for μ using f = 3mg and N₁ = 2mg cot φ to get μ = (3/2) tan φ.
The dynamic (and maximum static) coefficient of friction required between sphere A and the left wall is μ = √3 / 2 ≈ 0.866.
